dt: {bc}a cut of meat consisting of a thigh
{bc}an actor performing in an exaggerated theatrical style
{bc}someone who enjoys performing and who tends to behave in an exaggerated or playful way when people are watching

dt.t: A bit of a {wi}ham{/wi}, she's been collecting these one-liners for decades.
" … I was always sort of a {wi}ham{/wi}. I talk a lot. I'm wild. I was always performing growing up … "

dt: {bc}a licensed operator of an amateur radio station
{bc}a cushion used especially by tailors for pressing curved areas of garments

et: Middle English {it}hamme, homme{/it} "back of the knee, hock of a quadruped," going back to Old English {it}hamm, homm{/it} (strong feminine) "back of the knee," going back to Germanic {it}*hammō-, *hamō-{/it} (whence also Middle Dutch {it}hamme{/it} "back of the knee, shank," Old High German {it}hamma, hama{/it} (feminine weak noun) "hollow of the knee, calf, hock," {it}hammo{/it} (masculine weak noun) "hock," Old Norse {it}hǫm{/it} "back of the leg, haunch (of a horse)," going back to an Indo-European ablauting paradigm {it}*konh{inf}2{/inf}-m-, *kn̥h{inf}2{/inf}-m-os,{/it} whence also Old Irish {it}cnáim{/it} "bone," Greek {it}knḗmē{/it} "shank, tibia"); (sense 3) probably short for {et_link|hamfatter|hamfatter}

The presumption is that the Germanic etymon is a generalization of the nominative form, while the Celtic and Greek etyma maintained the oblique form. The geminate {it}-mm-{/it} in the Germanic words is most likely a reduction of {it}*-nm-{/it}; G. Kroonen ({it}Etymological Dictionary of Proto-Germanic,{/it} Brill, 2013) explains the variation between single and double {it}-m-{/it} as "analogical degemination [loss of gemination] in the nominative case of an n-stem paradigm."
shortdef: a buttock with its associated thigh —usually used in plural
a cut of meat consisting of a thigh; especially : one from a hog
